baseline_groups.claim_summary: Higher malaria ecology suitability is associated with higher slave population shares in the early United States, reflecting the relative productivity advantage of African labor in malaria-prone areas.
baseline_groups.notes: The 1860 full-controls spec (baseline_1860_full) is the strongest: coef=0.192 (p<0.001). The 1790 full-controls spec (baseline_full) is weaker: coef=0.065 (p=0.156). 95% of all specs show positive coefficients, 67% are significant at 5%.

global_notes: Paper studies malaria ecology and slavery in early US. County-level cross-sectional analysis with state FE. 76 total specs. Multiple baseline variants across 1790/1860 data and control sets. The 1860 results are stronger than 1790. Alternative malaria measures (MAL_temp, MAL_risk, MAL_clim) all confirm the finding. Political outcome specs (voting patterns) provide supporting but secondary evidence.
